articles.headline: Neel Kashkari’s Quiet Path to Pimco
articles.snippet: In joining Pimco, Neel Kashkari, the former Treasury bailout chief, settled on a financial company that didn’t need a government rescue but may be strengthening its federal ties.
articles.abstract: In joining Pimco, Neel Kashkari, the former Treasury bailout chief, settled on a financial company that didn’t need a government rescue but may be strengthening its federal ties.
articles.lead_paragraph: The financial crisis did not produce many stars. One of the few was Neel T. Kashkari, the former Bush administration bailout chief.

articles.headline: C.I.A. Takes On Bigger and Riskier Role on Front Lines
articles.snippet: The deaths of seven C.I.A. operatives in Afghanistan have highlighted the agency’s transformation to a paramilitary organization at the vanguard of America’s wars.
articles.abstract: The deaths of seven C.I.A. operatives in Afghanistan have highlighted the agency’s transformation to a paramilitary organization at the vanguard of America’s wars.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The deaths of seven Central Intelligence Agency operatives at a remote base in the mountains of Afghanistan are a pointed example of the civilian spy agency’s transformation in recent years into a paramilitary organization at the vanguard of America’s far-flung wars.

articles.headline: Doubts on Regulation and Renewal Hang Over Wall St.
articles.snippet: With the possibility of hefty profits and bonuses at banks, rarely has the divide been so deep between Wall Street and Main Street.
articles.abstract: With the possibility of hefty profits and bonuses at banks, rarely has the divide been so deep between Wall Street and Main Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: After staging one of the most remarkable comebacks in business history  because of taxpayer lifelines and other support from Washington  the giants of the banking industry are entering a new phase of the postbailout period.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Bomb Takes Heavy Toll at Pakistan Sports Event
articles.snippet: In a village organizing to resist the Taliban, a suicide bomber targeted civilian families, killing at least 89 people.
articles.abstract: In a village organizing to resist the Taliban, a suicide bomber targeted civilian families, killing at least 89 people.
articles.lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Taliban militants underscored their determination on Friday to prevent Pakistani citizens from forming armed militias to keep them at bay, as a suicide bomber rammed a truck loaded with hundreds of pounds of explosives into families and children crowded on a playground in the northwest.
articles.byline: By Ismail Khan and Richard A. Oppel Jr
